author: Vicki Hyman | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: N.J. gay rights activist faults Steve Carell portrayal of him in 'Freeheld'
text:
N.J. gay rights activist faults Steve Carell portrayal of him in 'Freeheld' freeheld-steve-carell Steve Carell, right, stars as real-life New Jersey gay civil rights lawyer Steven Goldstein, left, in the new drama "Freeheld." (Goldstein, Star-Ledger file photo/Carell, Lionsgate) 
Steven Goldstein, the Garden State Equality founder who fought for dying Ocean County detective Laurel Hester in the gay civil rights case dramatized in "Freeheld," has called Steve Carell, who plays him in the film, "a great guy who's a better me than me." 
Well .... 
Goldstein tells critic Michael Musto, who lauded "Freeheld" in the gay publication Out and singled out Carell's "hilarious" portrayal of Goldstein as "a campy, media-savvy queen," that he does have issues with his depiction — specifically, that he's not nearly as unrelentingly campy as Carell (and, to be fair, the script) would have you believe. "It's not like I'm a quiet Buddhist monk. You can't say that either. But of course, like other LGBT people, I have a sense of camp, and I'm ready with the soundbites, but what this movie does is that's what the character exclusively focuses on. I get it — the character is a catalyst, a supporting role. You don't see the behind the scenes negotiation. The movie didn't show the inside game. But if the movie's going to further the understanding of how we won equality, I'm happy. I've seen it six times, with friends and family. There are moments where they say, 'Steven, that's you' and moments where they say, 'I don't know who that is.'" Many of the lines in the film are verbatim from the battle to award Hester's domestic partner her pension, but some, Goldstein says, "are simply preposterous," and he also says the "catfight" between him and Hester's supportive police partner, played by Michael Shannon, never happened. Make no mistake — Goldstein loves the movie, but, he says, "I'm looking forward to the day where I'm not just Jack from 'Will & Grace' with a yarmulke or Jm. J Bullock from 'Too Close For Comfort.' LGBTs are complex people."
